lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters, locations, and ways to travel mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before listening, write “bank,” “bus,” “walk,” and other key words on the board. Students listen and circle which ones they hear.
stretchStrategies: Story Map Rebuild – After acting the story, students work in groups to redraw the journey of the characters on a blank map, adding who went where and how (on foot, by bus). Groups present their map version.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Assign roles in the story. Students act out using props or flashcards and then ask/answer questions about transport used.
stretchStrategies: Story Map Rebuild – After acting the story, students work in groups to redraw the journey of the characters on a blank map, adding who went where and how (on foot, by bus). Groups present their map version.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or performing it.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Pause the story before the end. Ask: “What happens next?” Students draw and present their own endings.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

Certain common places will not overlap in style or popular concept with their Western equivalents (fire station, post office, bakery, library), whereas others are more comparable (hair salon, shopping centre)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
